title: Lawyer for young adult at center of BBC scandal says claims presenter broke law are 'rubbish'
description: The Metropolitan Police has also said they are not launching an investigation into the matter. Parents of the young adult tell 'The Sun' they stand by their accusations.

title: Turkey drops veto, agrees to back Swedish NATO bid
description: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan had attempted to block Sweden's membership, accusing Stockholm of harboring Kurdish activists. Sweden would be the 32nd country to join the NATO alliance.

title: Dutch Prime Minister Rutte surprises all by announcing retirement from politics
description: In power since 2010, the liberal defended a drastic limitation of the right to asylum, unacceptable to his allies in the center and center-left. This provoked an election where he seemed to be the favorite until he announced he would not be standing.

title: From shantytowns to utopia, then riots: The unique history of Nanterre
description: The city where Nahel M. grew up and was killed by a police officer on June 27 igniting days of unrest in several cities across France is a gateway to Paris. The skyscrapers of La Défense business district sit alongside working-class neighborhoods.

title: Russian attack on humanitarian aid point kills five, reports Ukraine
description: Five people were killed and more than a dozen injured after Russian shelling on an aid point, deemed a 'war crime' by the regional governor.

title: Last week was the hottest worldwide on record: UN
description: The first week in July was the hottest week every recorded, as a new study says  more than 61,000 people died due to the heat during Europe's record-breaking summer last year.

title: Team USA doctor Nassar, convicted of sexually assaulting gymnasts, stabbed in prison
description: The disgraced physician, who was found guilty of assaulting hundreds of athletes, was stabbed twice in the neck, six times in the chest and twice in the back, according to a prison official.

title: 'I Inside the Old Year Dying': The bewitching nature of PJ Harvey
description: The British singer-songwriter drew inspiration from her own poetry for her 10th album, fed by the landscapes and atmosphere of her native Dorset.

title: 'A parenthesis of national unity for the Paris 2024 Games is far from guaranteed'
description: Beginning on July 9, Paris 2024 teams will be carrying out operational tests. Meanwhile, several threats hang over the serenity of the Games.

title: Women's Tour de France 2024 to start in Rotterdam
description: The race will begin the day after the end of the Paris Olympic Games and spend three out of eight stages in the Netherlands, a powerhouse of women's cycling.

title: Louvre to host Macron-Modi Bastille Day dinner
description: The Indian prime minister is the guest of honor at this year's celebration of France's national holiday.

title: UK extradites man wanted over Channel drowning of 27 migrants to France
description: The man is suspected of being a member of the organized crime group that arranged for the unsafe boat crossing of at least 29 people, only two of whom survived.

title: Kremlin says Putin met with Prigozhin days after Wagner mutiny
description: According to a spokesman, Putin offered an 'assessment' of Wagner's actions on the battlefield in Ukraine and 'of the events of June 24.'

title: How climate change could make France uninsurable
description: Drought, hail, storms: In 2022, a series of disasters caused insurance payouts to soar. Now the outlook for climate risk is calling into question the very ability to insure.

title: Erdogan says Turkey could approve Sweden joining NATO in return for EU bid
description: 'First, open the way to Turkey's membership of the European Union, and then we will open it for Sweden,' President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said in a television appearance.

title: French state excessively 'dependent' on consulting firms, Court of Audit confirms
description: A report published Monday notes how the state has been increasingly relying on consultants, including for missions that could be handled by the administration itself. Expenditure on these contracts has soared under Emmanuel Macron's presidency.

title: US allies express reservations over cluster munition deliveries to Ukraine
description: The 2008 Oslo Convention, signed by many NATO countries but not the United States, Russia or Ukraine, bans these weapons capable of causing extensive civilian damage.

title: Geneva, a nest of Russian spies
description: Western countries have expelled dozens of Russian agents under diplomatic cover since the start of the war in Ukraine last year, except Switzerland. Moscow is using the opportunity to increase its presence in the country.

title: Dutch PM Rutte to leave politics after next general election
description: Mark Rutte said he planned to leave politics – but that his decision was 'personal' and had nothing to do with the recent collapse of his government.

title: Following riots in France, the far right pits the banlieues against rural towns
description: Marine Le Pen's Rassemblement National has been alleging rural France has been neglected compared to working-class immigrant suburbs. But the facts contradict the claim.

title: LGBTQ+ rights: French government's new plan puts emphasis on training
description: France is introducing on Monday a new set of measures to fight discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity.

title: BBC presenter suspended over explicit photo claims
description: The British broadcaster said it had suspended a – so far unidentified – presenter after allegations that he had paid a minor for sexually explicit images.

title: How the Tunisian fishing village of Ellouza has become a migrant graveyard
description: This village is only 150km from Lampedusa and is a high-risk departure point for sub-Saharan migrants trying to reach Europe. On Sunday, another boat sank off the Tunisian coast, killing one person and leaving a dozen others missing.

title: Uzbek president cements power after winning third term
description: Shavkat Mirziyoyev is set to run the Central Asian country until 2030 after winning an election on Sunday with 87% of the vote.

title: Children killed in kindergarten attack in China
description: A teacher, two parents and three pupils were among those killed at the attack in Guangdong province on Sunday morning.

title: Wembanyama more aggressive in stronger second Summer League game with Spurs in Las Vegas
description: The No. 1 pick in this year’s draft looked much more like himself in his second game of Summer League on Sunday. He finished with 27 points and 12 rebounds, but the Spurs lost 85-80 to the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Belarus, a relative threat to the West
description: While Poland and the Baltic states are deeply concerned by Minsk's actions, NATO remains fairly calm about the risks posed by Alexander Lukashenko's regime.

title: UN peacekeeping missions are losing steam in Africa
description: Deemed costly, overstaffed, overly centralized and ineffective, the continent's blue helmet contingents could be replaced by regional organizations financed by the UN or, as is increasingly the case in reality, by paramilitary groups.

title: Welcome to Giverny, home of the painter and gardener Claude Monet
description: The garden of Monet's Giverny house, with its famous water lilies bordering on abstraction and the Japanese green bridge that he often depicted in his canvases, was designed by the impressionist painter as a work of art.

title: Seabed mining: growing calls for a 'precautionary pause'
description: A new round of negotiations within the International Seabed Authority is scheduled from July 10 to 28 in Kingston, Jamaica. While the ranks of those opposed to exploitation are growing, some countries and companies are keen to move ahead quickly.

title: One dead and three missing in landslides in southwestern Japan
description: The country's weather agency warned on Monday of the 'heaviest rain ever' in the region. The prime minister's office said a task force had been established to coordinate a response to the rains.

title: Despite the war in Ukraine, NATO is still searching for credible plans for Europe's eastern flank
description: With the Atlantic Alliance summit due to open in Vilnius on July 11, the build-up of its rapid reaction force remains uncertain.
